We have a broadly positive view of Hexagon's strategy and product set while we see new management off to a good start, taking the right actions to return the business back to better growth. However, given a challenging macro backdrop and slow development in some of Hexagon's key end markets, we see cyclical headwinds persisting for now, impairing growth potential. A proposed break-up into two companies could unlock hidden value but would also require operational improvements at both companies but especially Octave. We view the business as fairly valued here and rate Hexagon Hold.

We value Hexagon using a SOTP valuation after the company's proposed split into the Octave NewCo (mostly former ALI) and Hexagon RemainCo as well as the recent Design & Engineering asset sale deal to a leading US EDA player for E2.7b. We apply a FY26e EV/EBIT multiple of ~17x to Hexagon RemainCo, which represents a small discount to European Industrial peers. Conversely, Octave is valued at ~21x EV/EBIT, which implies a discount to global Engineering Software peers due to its currently subdued growth profile.

Key upside risks include: 1) more pronounced recovery in key end markets, i.e., Manufacturing & Construction or Geosytems in China; 2) greater-than-expected revenue & cost synergies from acquisitions; and 3) successful new product launches; 4) a takeover of Octave at an attractive premium (ahead of the anticipated spin-off). Downside risks include: 1) competitive share losses; 2) slower-thanexpected recovery in Manufacturing and Construction and a sustained downturn in Geosystems; and 3) Hexagon may experience less margin benefit from the introduction of new products than we expect.

Mensch und Maschine (MuM) is a leading European Autodesk partner providing software and digitization services for the architecture, engineering and construction (AEC) and manufacturing industries. A change in the accounting treatment of its Autodesk business as a result of the shift in Autodesk's go-tomarket motion temporarily distorts MuM's FY25 financials, we believe masking the underlying strength of the company. We see this transition year as an attractive entry point, with MuM trading at a significant discount to its 10-year EV/EBIT multiple. We believe shares can re-rate to historical valuation levels once MuM resumes its normal trajectory of robust EPS growth in '26/'27, driven by reaccelerating growth and margin expansion.

MuM combines a Software segment that can be compared to engineering software companies, while the Autodesk business exhibits characteristics of IT services and consulting. We, hence, use a SOTP approach when valuing MuM, as we believe the Autodesk VAR business should be valued differently from its fastergrowing,

highermargin Software business. We value the Software segment at ~22x EV/EBIT, at a 30% discount to the median of comparable engineering software companies. This discount reflects a slightly less dominant market position and the smaller TAM of MuM´s software brands, as well as a discount, given our estimates being slightly below consensus. The Digitization segment is valued at ~11x EV/EBIT, the median of a broad group of IT services and VAR peers. We adjust for minorities (with SOFiSTiK and DATAflor being fully consolidated in the Software segment), valued at ~20x P/E, a 30% discount to the median P/E of our engineering software peer group. Combined, we derive our target price. Hence, although our estimates for outer years are slightly below consensus, we view valuation levels as compelling and come to the conclusion of a Buy rating.

Key downside risks to our view include, but are not limited to: 1) MuM's dependence on Autodesk, 2) risks associated with changes in Autodesk's pricing model, 3) intensified competition and consolidation trends in the Autodesk partner channel, 4) MuM's exposure to cyclical end markets, 5) risks associated with innovation and technological advancements, 6) potentially value-destructive M&A activity in the future, and 7) risks associated with MuM's shareholder structure.

We believe that Nemetschek is well positioned as one of the leading suppliers of BIM software, outperforming the global AEC market with its strong multi-brand suite of products, including Bluebeam, Allplan, Graphisoft and Vectorworks. The company is the only player addressing each specific AEC niche market from the design of a building to its management - thus offering a gapless value chain and the ability to foster strong and diversified future growth. In addition, we expect inorganic effects from frequent earnings-accretive acquisitions in the global BIM stage. As Nemetschek stands out versus peers, we view a premium as justified. However, much of the potential appears to be priced in. Hence, we rate the stock Hold.

We value Nemetschek using a 50/50 blend of: 1) a ~42x FY26E P/E, and 2) a ~36x FY26E EV/uFCF. These valuation approaches represent ~50% / ~33% premiums to peer group average multiples, in line with the median premium Nemetschek traded at over the last 10 years. We view this as justified given its strong and consistent growth potential in the long term, strong margin expansion potential, as well as top management and agile company structure.

Key up/downside risks include: 1) stronger/weakening macroeconomic conditions in the AEC/O industry, which could affect demand; 2) launch of new products and new technology; 3) better/worse acquisition integration, 4) risks associated with the transition of customers to subscription-based pricing models (churn, faster/slower progress), 5) upside/downside risks associated with Nemetschek's internationalization and expansion into foreign markets (most notably India), and 6) adverse/favorable development in BIM regulation.

Netcompany is a digitally-focused IT Services business with a strong growth track record. We see Netcompany expanding into adjacent Northern European markets with a focus on multiyear public sector digital projects. We view the company's hiring strategy as a differentiator. While we are optimistic on its prospects and management, we see Netcompany as a more defensive name in the sector, less geared to a pending post-Covid recovery. Hold.

Our TP is based on an average of an ~18x FY26E P/E and an ~19x FY26E EV/uFCF, higher than traditional IT Services peers but lower than high-growth IT Services comps.

Key risks include: high exposure to the public sector and reputational risks, a worsening macro, slower RRF conversion rates, talent acquisition, wage inflation and execution risk from an acquired company on the downside; and growth, margin expansion, faster progression in the UK, Norway and Greece as well as faster integration of the acquired company ahead of forecasts on the upside.

Ocado continues to target reaching cash break-even during FY26. This is clearly an important milestone for the group. For equity holders, the slower rollout of the group's technology to its key grocery partners, including a recalibration of one key relationship have impacted confidence. The growth Ocado can achieve in Tech Solutions remains the key driver of equity value. We believe the ongoing shift of grocery to online, the significant productivity gains from the group's technology, the pressure grocery partners face in terms of labour shortage and cost will drive take up of modules ultimately leading to a highly profitable, cash-generative business. Importantly, Ocado's technology has evolved to include new fulfilment products that bring its technology to a wider range of applications, including Store Based Automation. This should allow its technology to be used by grocers/retailers wherever they are in their online journey. We expect Ocado to remain volatile but have a positive stance and a Buy rating.

We value the group on a sum-of-the-parts basis. Each division is valued on a DCF (11.5% WACC with 12.5% cost of equity and 10.5% cost of debt) and terminal growth of 3%. We value Ocado's 50% stake in ORL at c.£700m, Tech Solutions at c.£1.5bn and Logistics at c. £230m. We make further adjustments for OIA, net debt, other financial assets and tax loss carried forward.

Risks include: channel shift of grocery to online is slower than anticipated; grocery partners find it difficult to adopt the group's technology in the way that hastens rollouts, its foray into non-grocery do not progress in the way envisaged, competition intensifies whether in terms of direct competitors or indirect solutions; and cash flows aren't realised in time or in such a way that means more capital is required that is more expensive or dilutive.

Beyond the benefits of PTC's shift to subscription, we see the company as very well positioned to benefit from the theme of Digital Production, notably around CAD and PLM as well as AI where PTC has shown a promising roadmap. The company's strategic partnerships with industry leaders in their respective fields address gaps in PTC's portfolio and distribution capabilities, and are set to drive incremental revenue growth while the exit of the IoT business, where PTC had limited success in the past, should further improve group performance. Buy.

We value PTC based on a ~24x CY26E EV/uFCF multiple, broadly in line with key direct peers, reflecting improving execution but remaining challenges in certain end markets.

Key downside risks include: (a) a macroeconomic downturn, particularly in key manufacturing end markets for PTC; (b) competitive share losses; (c) failure to execute as successfully as we expect on the shift to subscriptions; (d) faster-thanexpected technological change causing disruption to PTC; and (e) M&A that is viewed unfavorably by investors or poorly executed.

Over the past decade, revenue has achieved a CAGR of 14% to €2,296m in FY24, and Reply has delivered a 16% CAGR in earnings per share to €5.7 in FY24. While growth has slowed from peak (MSD in FY25 from >10%), Reply's current organic growth rate is notably stronger than IT services peers. We believe this reflects: Reply's long-lasting relationships within its customer base (no customer >10% sales); high levels of specialism within the boutique network of companies; the value it delivers through focus on innovative technologies; strong execution; and a strong focus on up-sell and cross-sell through incentivisation structures. We believe this will enable Reply to continue to drive growth. Buy.

Our target price is based on a 13x CY26E EV/EBITDA target multiple. This is above the average of the peer set (11x CY25E EV/EBITDA based on the Bloomberg consensus), which we see as reflecting Reply's standout combination of growth and profitability amid a downturn in the IT services sector. This is also in line with our DCF result (WACC of 8.7%: 9% cost of equity, using a 3.5% risk-free rate, market risk premium of 6% and beta of 0.9; 6% interest on debt and 28% tax rate).

Key risks to the downside include: a further downturn in the environment for IT services spend; exposure to tariff-impacted end market risks associated with a high proportion of fixed-price contracts; risks associated with ongoing integration of acquired businesses; control of the network structure; and exposure to cyclical end markets.

| EBITDA Margin%                            | 23.2%  | 24.6%  | 27.5%  | 28.4%   | 29.1%   | 29.1%   |
| Net financial income/(expenses)           | -33    | -26    | -46    | -43     | -42     | -35     |
| Earnings before taxes (PBT) - adjusted    | 424    | 502    | 555    | 636     | 725     | 806     |
| Income tax expenses (non-IFRS)            | -95    | -120   | -132   | -151    | -172    | -191    |
| Tax rate (non-IFRS)                       | 22%    | 24%    | 24%    | 24%     | 24%     | 24%     |
| Net Income (adjusted)                     | 329    | 382    | 423    | 485     | 552     | 614     |
| Basic EPS (GBp)                           | 32.3   | 37.9   | 43.3   | 50.6    | 58.1    | 64.6    |
| Diluted adjusted Earnings per share (GBp) | 31.8   | 37.3   | 42.6   | 49.9    | 57.2    | 63.6    |

Sage is a major global accounting software vendor with a focus on SMEs. The company has gone through a significant investment phase in order to ensure it remains competitive. While operating margin is trending upwards again and pricing is increasing above historical averages, group growth has not delivered upside and remains below peers (~10%+), raising questions about expansion and new customer acquisition growth, in our view. Hence, we believe the stock warrants a discount to the global Software sector and see limited upside; Hold.

We are applying a 50/50 blend of 1) a ~25x CY26E P/E multiple; and 2) a ~22x CY26E EV/uFCF multiple, both representing a slight discount to peers to account for Sage's slower growth and/or still lower margins. We fully adjust our valuation metrics and Sage's peer group for share-based compensation (treating this as cost in P&L and CF metrics).

Key upside/downside risks include: 1) Sage may make acquisitions that are value enhancing or destructive, 2) Sage may be more/less successful than we expect in migrating its installed base to subscription at premium rates, 3) Sage may be more/ less successful than we expect in developing a Cloud-native successor product to its core product offerings, 4) Sage may find more/less cost savings than we expect to drive margin expansion, and 5) Sage may be more/less successful in acquiring new customers than we forecast.

SAP has a strong franchise as a leader in core application software, and we believe the company is making significant progress migrating its customer base to its Cloud offering around S/4HANA Cloud for ERP, while also winning new customers and continuing to grow outside ERP through its acquired Cloud businesses. SAP has now entered a "harvest" phase in 2024 with sustained multi-year, double-digit profitability growth and FCF expansion, supported by accelerating Cloud revenue growth and an efficiency program, which should drive further margin expansion beyond SAP's 2025 ambitions. We rate SAP Buy.

We value SAP at ~34x EV/uFCF, a slight premium to peers, accounting for share gains and faster earnings and FCF growth. This results in our price target, while our bull case analysis (faster Cloud migration of installed base, better underlying growth in the coming years) points to a potential valuation of E400 in the medium term.

Key risks to our thesis include: 1) market share loss in ERP as SAP transitions its clients to the Cloud; 2) emerging competition in its non-ERP Cloud businesses, driving share loss and/or pricing pressure; 3) failure to develop differentiated industry solutions for the Cloud and areas like AI, IoT or industry 4.0 through its expanding partner network; 4) political/macro shocks impacting the IT investment environment; 5) FX; and 6) potentially value-destructive M&A.

SoftwareONE, an IT Services company and Software/Cloud reseller, is aligned to key secular Software & IT Services trends among its clients as they drive digital transformation. These secular trends are expected to drive expansion in the company's IT Services TAM and growth in Software and Cloud product sales. However, the company's focus on bolt-on acquisitions to support the top-line growth is expected to act as a headwind for margins in the medium term. We remain cautious on the name. Hold.

We have updated our model and now value SoftwareOne at 12x '26e PF P/E, representing a discount to avg of peers at 19x. The lower multiple reflects underperformance in North America, execution and integration risks, as well as potentially weaker year-end budget flush in Dec, which could pose some downside risk to the company's FY25 guidance.

Downside risks include: dependence on a single major supplier, longer-thananticipated timeline to positive impact of GTM strategy, potential requirement to ramp onshore headcount as professional services business expand, negatively impacting margins, and lower synergies from the recent acquisition. Upside risks: faster-than-expected growth and margin expansion, higher synergies from the recent acquisition.

TeamViewer is an established player in the remote control software market, a large market that industry analysts expect to post a ~15% CAGR in the medium term, driven by digitization as well as vertical alignments with secular megatrends in the Industry 4.0 sphere. We believe TeamViewer is differentiated from its competitors in some technical aspects but is currently facing stronger price competition on its user base and is realizing slower progress on its Enterprise sales efforts, partially due to lackluster execution. Slow progress on diversifying its SME-heavy customer base into stickier and larger Enterprise deals, combined with increasing competitive pressure from the lower-end, significantly reduce visibility on the company's outlook and we rate the stock Hold.

We value TeamViewer on a 50/50 blend of FY26E P/E and EV/EBITDA of ~6x and ~8x, respectively, significant discounts to the broader software sector. The valuation reflects still a show-me story, lack of confidence in the company's enterprise pipeline conversion, and potential risks from a recessionary shock to its core SME customers, who currently still represent a material portion of overall billings.

Key downside risks include: 1) increasing competition on the free user base; 2) sequentially lower NRR than the current run rate; 3) possible revision of targets as the demand environment deteriorates as well as potentially lower margins from a higher cost base given the volatile billings mix. Key upside risks include: 1) potential consolidation candidate, given M&A interest in the sector; 2) continued cost containment measures offsetting increases in FTEs and salary inflation; and 3) an improving demand environment for enterprise as well as a material ramp up in IoT/ AR contribution to billings.

Temenos is a leader in the core banking software market, a large market that industry analysts expect to grow at an ~8% CAGR over the medium term, driven by digitization, regulation, and a switch from in-house to third-party software as banks look to reduce total cost of ownership. We believe that Temenos is differentiated from its competitors by its sustained high level of product development investment and strong ecosystem partnerships. However, we believe the Covid-19 pandemic resulted in a more challenging end-market environment among banks for some time and that core banking initiatives may drop down the IT agenda as a result. We rate the stock a Hold.

Our target price is based on a simple average of: 1) ~19x our FY27 EPS estimate, and 2) ~18x EV/uFCF on our estimated FY27 uFCF. Both are in line with their peers.

Key upside risks include: 1) a less-severe downturn in the banking industry than we expect, 2) a mega-deal signing boosting license revenue, 3) more traction in expansion markets than we expect, and 4) subscription and SaaS revenue ramping up faster than anticipated. Key downside risks include: 1) a more severe downturn in the banking industry than we expect, 2) execution misses on implementation, 3) share loss to competition, and 4) execution misses on SaaS and subscription that leads to medium-term targets being revisited.
